In a static Poissonian network, the epidemic threshold β
c is simply

0
. Notice that while we recover this result in the limit
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\Delta \to 0$$\end{document}
Δ → 0
, our critical transmission rate is not simply that of a Poissonian network with average degree
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${k}_{0}+\Delta $$\end{document}
k
0
+ Δ
. On the one hand, the degree distribution of infected node is of smaller variance than a Poisson distribution, which raises the epidemic threshold. On the other hand, there is a feedback between the expected epidemic size and the average degree of the network which lowers the epidemic threshold. Our steady state analysis is illustrated in Fig. S6 as a function of model parameters.
